so github actions is the product name and what you do is you build workflows

the process that you want to happen files so they are white space sensitive
you have to keep that into account and they go in a special directory in your github repo
so in the in the root of your repo you're going to have to define a dot github folder and in that folder you're going to
define a workflows folder and that's where all of your workflow files will go there's an example workflow file here
here on the right and these workflows could do pretty much anything that the id it can trigger off
different events that are happening inside of github for example somebody submits a new issue you can have a workflow that

so the workflows are the files we're going to build workflows are triggered off event
and those events are could be like i said a push or a pull to a pull request or a particular branch

has work goes wrong like that and the documentation on github actions is very

now in addition to being called github actions as a product there are also things to add to your
workflows which are called actions and actions are think of them as tasks they're reusable
code that could be used by your different workflow files and these actions can be you can build
your own action you can go out to the marketplace and get actions usually they're built using either node.js or they can be running a
container using any any language some examples of actions that we have out there um that a lot of people use are like
there's a stale action so you can scan your repo for issues and pull requests that haven't been touched
in a while there's an azure web app action if you want to be able to deploy that to say an azure web app we're going to
use that one today then there's an action there that we can use to be able to um deploy out and just kind of

to look at so you can go to the repo where the action was was defined and see exactly how the
action works if you want to dive into the code obviously don't want to do is be
personal access tokens or logins into your source code directly so
you need to be storing those in a secret it's to be used in say azure vault to be
able to store your secrets but github also provides you ability to store secrets and at multiple levels
you can store them at the organization so that all your repos or some of your repos can access those secrets
you can store them at the repository level so that all the workflows in a repository can access those secrets
or you could store them in a repository environment level so something new that we just released
in beta in december is the ability to define environments
and that allows me to specify secrets that only apply to that particular environment speaking
of environments currently in beta so if you're using environments you can define say a dev
environment or a qa environment or a production environment and then you can take the jobs in your
workflow and target those environments and when you target a job at an environment you can define
rules such as required reviewers people that have to approve the job before it can run
or wait time it has to wait a certain amount of time before it can run and you can define environment level
secrets for example you may have different azure keys or aws
keys for accessing devs that you do accessing prod and you can define those keys in those
specific environments but only jobs that target those environments
can use those keys now you have a way to obviously run
these workflows and that's what runners do you have both hosted runners which
github maintains for you up in the cloud we have linux windows and mac runners we maintain those we make sure
they're upgraded they come with pre-installed software most of the things you might need to be able to do your builds or do your
deploys you can also use these free if you're using public repos which is really nice for open source projects
but and of course the software that we use for um is versus open source you go out to the
actions from a repo and actually see that software but some companies want to run their own
runners they don't want hosted ones so therefore we provide a self-hosted option you can spin up your
own vm install the runner software and then you're able to maintain that vm
with what it needs for your builds it could be you need to do this because you need to keep everything behind your
firewall it could be you have certain third-party tools that need to be installed
